data.title: John Sladek, RIP
data.text: On Sun, 12 Mar 2000 13:40:56 GMT, Steven H Silver carefully left the following thoughtprints where they could be seen: >Mike Resnick is reporting the death of SF author John Sladek at age 63 >from lung disease. > >Steven As it was reported to me for the SFWA Online Update, John Sladek died the morning of March 10, of an inherited "progressive lung disease" with which he had been struggling for some time. He was apparently a candidate for a lung transplant, and there was one report that he was turned down for one earlier in the week and "just gave up" in the wake of that disappointment. All of the other reports I've seen give his age as 62. He's survived by a wife, daughter, and granddaughter. I have no information on services, memorials, or charities, but if any comes in, it will be added to the obit on the SFWA Web site (http://www.sfwa.org). Best, K-Mac -- Tomorrow morning, all of the guns will stop working. --What will happen tomorrow night?-- THE TRIGGER by Arthur C. Clarke & Michael Kube-McDowell Published by Bantam Spectra (US) and HarperCollins (UK) In message , Michael P. Kube-McDowell (K-...@sff.net) wrote: > All of the other reports I've seen give his age as 62. He's survived > by a wife, daughter, and granddaughter. I have no information on > services, memorials, or charities, but if any comes in, it will be > added to the obit on the SFWA Web site Thanks for the pointer to his obituary, K-Mac. Sladek authored The Muller-Fokker Effect in 1970. A brilliant satiric novel. The Amazon.com blurb does not do it justice. Apologies for the error. Here it is. SF Novels: The Reproductive System (1968) [aka Mechasm] The Muller-Fokker Effect (1970) Roderick (1980) Roderick at Random (1983) Tik-Tok (1983) Bugs (1989) Blood and Gingerbread (1990) Short Stories & Collections: The Steam Driven Boy and Other Strangers (1973) Keep the Giraffe Burning (1977) The Best of John Sladek (1981) Alien Accounts (1982) The Lunatics of Terra (1984) Flatland (1982) Red Noise (1982) Love Among the Xoids (1984) Non SF Fiction: Black Aura (1974) The Book of Clues (1984) Invisible Green (1977) Collaborations & nome-de-plumes: Black Alice (1968) with Thomas Disch [as Thom Demijohn] Clara Reeve (1975) with Thomas Disch [as Leonie Hargrave] The House that Fear Built (1966) with Thomas Disch [as Cassandra Knye] The Castle and the Key (1967) as Cassandra Knye Nonfiction: The New Apocrypha (1973) Using XyWrite II (1987) Judgment of Jupiter (1980) as Richard Tilms Arachne Rising (1977) as James Vogh The Cosmic Factor (1978) as James Vogh  On Sun, 12 Mar 2000 18:57:22 -0000, "Michael Davis" carefully left the following thoughtprints where they could be seen: >It wasn't the facts surrounding his death. It was about his career.  Just to clarify, Matthew, I did not write the obit on the SFWA Web site; I only write (when necessary) the obits for the SFWA Online Update, an e-mail newsletter. I don't enjoy the job, but it comes with being the editor. In this case, I drew heavily on John Clute's very flattering (and, I think, respectably complete) profile of Sladek in THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF SCIENCE FICTION. As it happens, Clute does mention all four collections of short fiction, though in practically the same breath he alludes to "the oddly uncommercial course of [Sladek's] career." I wouldn't be surprised to learn that Sladek had a higher profile in the UK than in the US. The New Wave was 30+ years ago, and the half-life of reader awareness nowadays seems to be about six months. Notwithstanding the passion of Sladek's fans and admirers, I think Sladek was probably not even on the radar of most American SF readers. (Which raises the question, just how big is the natural audience for experimental literary fiction, whatever the genre?) The closest he came to a mass-market presence was probably the DAW edition of TIK-TOK, and that was 15 years ago. Clute seems to imply that it was never any different, closing Sladek's profile with what sounds like a plea: "We need his attention; he deserves ours."  On Sun, 12 Mar 2000 18:57:22 -0000, "Michael Davis" carefully left the following thoughtprints where they could be seen: > Or that he could not get his later >work published. That, sadly, is becoming a fact of life in a business which has fewer "book people" and more computerized sales reports influencing what gets published. A lot of writers who have an audience--just not a big enough one--have been hitting the wall. Perhaps print-on-demand and digital publishing will eventually offer an alternative that will allow writers who do not have the broader appeal demanded by the mass-market publishing equation to continue their careers. POD and DP may also be the only hope for the backlist--especially the backlist of the midlisters who are being squeezed the hardest. K-Mac - Michael P. Kube-McDowell, co-author of THE TRIGGER - Utility sideman for the world's loudest filk ensemble, The Black Book Band - info at www.sff.net/people/K-Mac - Partly responsible for FIRST CONTACT (Dodeka DR-10011D) Michael P. Kube-McDowell writes: >I wouldn't be surprised to learn that Sladek had a higher profile in >the UK than in the US. The New Wave was 30+ years ago, and the >half-life of reader awareness nowadays seems to be about six months. . . . Sladek never seriously hit my radar, possibly because I was a naive reader when I encountered him and never went back. But I must respectfully disagree with Michael about the six-month half life. If that were true, there would be a number of SF writers whose quality has declined such that they're essentially living off their names (no specifics, there's already a deeply depressing discussion of the decline of Larry Niven and we don't need more). Once the name is well-known it tends to stick in peoples' heads. Perhaps this is why series are so popular with publishers -- you don't have to remember author names and associate a new book with his previous books. You only have to remember the general story. You only have to remember the general story. That's one of the things I dislike about series, even those that I find enjoyable on the whole: unless I've recently (re)read the prior book, I spend the first half of the book going "Who was that person/place/thing again?" (Or else, "Grrr! Why is the author wasting time telling me what I already know, using the exact same phrasing as the last time around?") -- Julie Stampnitzky http://www.yucs.org/~jules Rehovot, Israel http://neskaya.darkover.cx On Wed, 15 Mar 2000, Sandra Bond wrote: > I used to use 'Slaydeck' until I found fandom and discovered everyone > called him 'Sladdeck', so I changed my ways on the basis that they > probably knew better than me. I'd never have thought of 'Slaadeck'. Oh, right, a lot of the people who post here are active fans, and will have heard the "correct" pronunciation at clubs and cons. I'm just guessing, but I suppose the name must come from Polish or Czech or something like that, so the original Old Country pronunciation must be something like "Slahdek" or "Shlahdek"; and I'd have expected a lot of people to say "Slahdek" on that basis. > I also used to talk of -- or rather, in those pre-fandom days, think of, > as I didn't have anyone to talk to about him -- Clifford D. 'Symak' > instead of Simmack, which is the usual usage in fandom. (I always wonder > if that name ultimately derives from ancient Greek 'symmachos', meaning > 'twin'.) What a coincidence: two science fiction writers from the Minneapolis area, both having names that begin with S, end with k, and are commonly mispronounced. Kube-McDowell writes: > >>I wouldn't be surprised to learn that Sladek had a higher profile in >>the UK than in the US. The New Wave was 30+ years ago, and the >>half-life of reader awareness nowadays seems to be about six months. > . . . > >Sladek never seriously hit my radar, possibly because I was a naive reader >when I encountered him and never went back. > >But I must respectfully disagree with Michael about the six-month half >life. If that were true, there would be a number of SF writers whose >quality has declined such that they're essentially living off their names >(no specifics, there's already a deeply depressing discussion of the >decline of Larry Niven and we don't need more). Once the name is >well-known it tends to stick in peoples' heads. Hi, Steve. FWIW, I was speaking primarily of the much larger number of midlist writers rather than toplist people like Larry Niven. Because books go out of print so quickly now, and because backlist is so rarely reissued, most writers have little to no presence in the racks when they're "between books." That situation favors those who write more quickly, two or three novels a year, over those who write more slowly, a novel every year or two or three. The former stay in the consciousness of the readers and booksellers; the latter fade from consciousness. In extreme cases, they can even find themselves cast as a "first novelist" again and again. And even writers of substantial reputation are affected by this dynamic when they stop writing or die. I actually had an editor for a major imprint take a pass on a cover blurb from Fred Pohl for one of my novels, explaining in response to my stunned protestations that Pohl "wasn't a big enough name." >Perhaps this is why series are so popular with publishers -- you don't >have to remember author names and associate a new book with his previous >books. You only have to remember the general story. Television has made us very familiar with and comfortable with the conventions of episodic storytelling. Maybe even more than "comfortable with"--maybe "fond of." A successful series becomes a Brand Name, with all the attendant marketing advantages. I think that most writers would like to become Brand Names themselves; failing that, creating a Brand Name series is the next best thing (though see entry for "golden handcuffs"). Best, K-Mac -- Tomorrow morning, all of the guns will stop working. --What will happen tomorrow night?-- THE TRIGGER by Arthur C. (Or else, "Grrr! Why is the author wasting time telling me what I >already know, using the exact same phrasing as the last time around?") One of the things I found striking in Thomas Harris's _Red Dragon_ and _The Silence of the Lambs_ is a key repetition. In both novels, the main character (Will Graham in the first, Clarice Starling in the second) are briefed by Dr. Chilton about the dangers of dealing with Hannibal Lecter and how important it is not to give him anything to use. In both novels, Chilton describes what happened to a nurse whom Lecter managed to assault while in captivity. In the two novels, Chilton's recounting of the incident is verbatim, which gives it the feeling of a rehearsed lecture--"Here's my script on what I tell people who are visiting Lecter"--that adds a bit to Chilton's character. -- Kevin Maroney | kmar...@crossover.com Kitchen Staff Supervisor, New York Review of Science Fiction > For a time Sladek seemed almost obsessed with debunking > Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics. RODERICK, TIK-TOK, and the Asimov > parody all take different tacks at destroying the premise of all > Asimov's robot stories. I always thought that was shooting fish in > a barrel, but given the relative popularity of the Asimov robot > stories vs. Sladek's own work, maybe the satire needed wider > circulation. <<>> They're fun for the logic-problem/word-game stories Asimov wrote, and I enjoy the Asimov stories for what they are. I'm willing to bet Sladek did, too. But in terms of technology, or any relationship to the actual operation of an artificial intelligence, the Three Laws of Robotics are total nonsense. Any program or entity capable of handling abstract concepts like "harm" is perforce inherently capable of circumventing dictates about them. That was Sladek's point -- or one of them, anyway. I don't have the works to hand, so I can't summarize his various other attacks. Still, understand: It was all in good fun. To my mind, Sladek demonstrated an obvious affection for the Laws of Robotics by writing about them so amusingly, and by returning to the subject so often. I think Sladek wasn't attacking Asimov as such, or calling Asimov a stupid writer -- rather, just as Asimov's characters had to think logically about the semantic wording of the Laws in so many stories, Sladek was asking SF fans to think more logically about the premise of the Laws themselves. -- Allen Varney Remove second aol.com to reply by e-mail On Sat, 18 Mar 2000 18:33:16 +0800, Paul Andinach wrote: >On 13 Mar 2000, Allen Varney wrote: > >> For a time Sladek seemed almost obsessed with debunking >> Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics. RODERICK, TIK-TOK, and the Asimov >> parody all take different tacks at destroying the premise of all >> Asimov's robot stories. I always thought that was shooting fish in >> a barrel, but given the relative popularity of the Asimov robot >> stories vs. Sladek's own work, maybe the satire needed wider >> circulation. > >Curiousity: What d[id Sladek|o you] think to be wrong with Asimov's >Laws of Robotics? They were just a story premise. Asimov was perfectly aware of that, if they didn't admit ambiguity most of his robot stories wouldn't exist. The "laws" are human-type laws. They depend on a whole lot of assumptions and definitions. Asimov told the story about when he went to see the movie "2001". When Hal started killing the crew, he stood up in his seat and exclaimed "Hal's breaking First Law!". His companion said, "So Isaac, strike him with lightning." I'm more than a >>little boggled that anyone would think of pronouncing Clough >>any other way. > >One must then ask, how do you pronounce slough, plough, though, >trough, through, cough? > >(After typing so many gh's, I must confess, I look at these words and >am more than a little boggled that they all aren't pronounced with a >hard "g".) They're *supposed* to all be pronounced with a 'yogh' which is a sort of aspirated 'g', and represented by a letter which doesn't exist anymore, which was a 'z' with a curly tail. The best example I know of is the 'gh' in 'Edinburgh'. There's also the 'z' in 'Iain Menzies Banks'. -- Del Cotter d...@branta.demon.co.uk Nancy Lebovitz wrote:  At this point in the series the bones of it are set, and I doubt that any change in the template is possible. (Although I do note that a drastic redesign of the covers was recently made manifest, which might be a straw in the wind.) But I do yearn for a book in which St. Germain not only does not go to someplace that was a center of the culture of his time, but in which he does not meet and become cozy with the most famous people of the area that are known to modern readers. How nice it would be if just once he hung out with ordinary schlubs and peasantry! And while he was at it he could have a relationship with a female that did not end in her death or dismemberment, and could associate with the religious heirarchy of his time in a non-adversarial manner. Just for a change, you understand.  In article <38F61787...@erols.com>,  Quinn has not yet devoted an entire book where St-Germain has been himself a member of "ordinary schlubs or peasantry" class but it has been a subplot in several of the books. For example, we see what he went through as a slave in Out of the House of Life; he was taken for ransom after being shipwrecked in Better in the Dark; he disguised himself as a musician in Blood Roses. He also has reflections of being a member of the lower class in a number of the books. As for him befriending members of "ordinary schlubs or peasantry", I can think of countless examples, including in the most recent book, Communion Blood (Tor 1999). Flipping through my copies of the series, I can think of several women Saint-Germain had relationships with that did not end in their death or dismemberment. Scroll down if interested :::Spoiler alerts::::: S P O I L E R S B E L O W We have Lucienne Cressie from Hotel Transylvania, Padmiri from Path of the Eclipse, Rowena Saxon from Writ in Blood, Harriet from "Cabin 33." I also believe that Amalija from Writ in Blood did not die from her relationship with St-G, and there was another character in Tempting Fate whom I can't recall. Madelaine de Montalia *did* die and become a vampire at her own will, as did Olivia Clemens (who later died the "True Death" but it had nothing to do with Saint-Germain"). A another female vampire is the subject of Quinn's forthcoming Saint-Germain novel, Come Twilight (Tor Books, Fall 2000). And from what I've heard, Csimenae is *quite* a change from the other female vampires Quinn has written about. Sent via Deja.com http://www.deja.com/ Before you buy. The point isn't that "Clough" should be >>obvious from the spelling, it's that it is, to my mind, sufficiently >>common that it should just be known, like all those others. > >Hmm? Maybe in England. The only place I've ever seen the word >"Clough" in my life is in Brenda's name. It's possible I've encountered >somebody else with that last name and simply don't remember, of >course, but still. Exactly. My first encounter with the name "Clough" was with a story by "B. W. Clough" (who is Brenda, of course) in Aboriginal SF some years ago. I made the wrong guess about pronunciation, and it stuck with me. (I would still maintain that the rhythm of B. W. Clo is better than B. W. Cluff, but I may just be being silly.) So: the pronunciation of "Clough" is not remotely obvious from the spelling, and as it's a rarish name in the US, it's certainly not "sufficiently common" that it would be known. 
